q: The LVN is reviewing a new client's advance directives which specify 'Do Not Resuscitate' (DNR). A family member demands that 'everything be done' if the client arrests. What is the LVN's primary legal responsibility?
answers: Respect the client's written wishes in the advance directive.
Follow the family member's wishes to avoid conflict.
Ask the charge nurse to make the final decision.
Explain that only a court order can override the directive.

q: Which of these care tasks can the LVN safely assign to an Unlicensed Assistive Personnel (UAP) for a client who is stable two days post-hip replacement?
answers: Assisting the client with ambulation to the bathroom.
Monitoring the surgical incision for signs of infection.
Teaching the client about the side effects of their pain medication.
Administering a scheduled oral analgesic.

q: During a care conference, the LVN discusses a client's progress with a physical therapist and a social worker. This is a primary example of what concept?
answers: Interprofessional collaboration.
Therapeutic communication.
Delegation of authority.
Client advocacy.

q: A client with limited English proficiency is scheduled for a procedure. The client's bilingual adult daughter offers to translate. What is the nurse's most appropriate action?
answers: Request a hospital-approved medical interpreter.
Allow the daughter to translate to build rapport.
Use a phone-based translation app to explain.
Document that the daughter translated and proceed.

q: The LVN receives a report on four clients at the start of a shift. Which client should the LVN prioritize for assessment first?
answers: A client with asthma who is reporting new-onset shortness of breath.
A client reporting chronic back pain, rated 3/10.
A client with stable vital signs who needs a routine dressing change.
A client scheduled for discharge awaiting their paperwork.

q: What is the primary purpose of a client's advance directive?
answers: To document the client's wishes for future medical care should they become unable to decide for themselves.
To assign power of attorney for managing the client's financial affairs.
To determine the client's insurance coverage and benefits for a hospital stay.
To list all approved family members who can visit the client.

q: An LVN observes a coworker documenting a procedure before it has been performed. What is the LVN's initial action?
answers: Report the observation directly to the nurse manager.
Ask the coworker if they need help completing the procedure.
Ignore the situation as it does not directly involve their patient.
Immediately confront the coworker in the hallway.

q: A client refuses a prescribed medication. The LVN has already explained the medication's purpose and benefits. What is the LVN's next step?
answers: Document the client's refusal and the reason, then notify the charge nurse or physician.
Administer the medication anyway, as it is prescribed for the client's benefit.
Tell the client they cannot refuse a medication ordered by the doctor.
Mix the medication in applesauce to ensure the client takes it.

q: The LVN is handing off care for a group of patients to the LVN on the next shift. Which piece of information is most critical to include in the handoff report?
answers: The client's code status and any recent changes in their condition.
The number of visitors the client had during the shift.
The LVN's personal opinion of the client's family members.
The schedule for routine vital signs for all patients.

q: A visitor brings a client a meal from home. The client is on a special diet prescribed by the physician. How should the LVN handle this situation?
answers: Politely explain the dietary restrictions to the client and visitor and remove the outside food.
Allow the client to have the meal since it will improve their morale.
Tell the visitor they have violated hospital policy and must leave.
Take a sample of the food to the lab for analysis before allowing the client to eat it.

q: An 80-year-old client is admitted with confusion. The client has a living will and durable power of attorney for health care, naming their son as their agent. The son disagrees with the living will's directives. Whose instructions should the healthcare team follow?
answers: The living will's directives.
The son's instructions as he is the power of attorney.
The instructions of the attending physician.
The hospital's ethics committee.

q: Which of the following tasks is appropriate for an LVN to delegate to a UAP?
answers: Recording intake and output for a stable client.
Performing a sterile dressing change.
Administering a scheduled nebulizer treatment.
Evaluating a client's response to pain medication.

q: A client is scheduled for surgery and states, 'I'm not sure if this is the right thing to do.' What is the LVN's role as a client advocate?
answers: Notify the surgeon that the client is having doubts and may not be giving informed consent.
Reassure the client that the surgeon is highly skilled and they have nothing to worry about.
Tell the client that they must sign the consent form to proceed with the surgery.
Ask a family member to convince the client to have the surgery.

q: The LVN must obtain informed consent from a client before a procedure. The client is alert but has been given a sedative medication. What is the LVN's most appropriate action?
answers: Wait to have the consent form signed until the effects of the medication have worn off.
Have the client sign the form immediately before the medication takes full effect.
Ask the client's next of kin to sign the consent form instead.
Proceed with the procedure as the doctor has already explained it.

q: Which client should the LVN prioritize and see first after receiving the morning report?
answers: A client with diabetes whose morning blood glucose is 60 mg/dL.
A client who needs assistance with their morning bath.
An elderly client who is awaiting discharge papers.
A client who is complaining of constipation for the past two days.

q: The SBAR technique is used for communication between healthcare professionals. What does the 'B' in SBAR stand for?
answers: Background.
Bedside.
Benefits.
Bleeding.

q: An LVN makes a medication error but the client has no apparent adverse effects. What is the LVN's first action?
answers: Assess the client for any changes and notify the charge nurse and physician.
Document the medication was given as ordered to avoid disciplinary action.
Wait to see if the client develops any symptoms before reporting the error.
Ask a coworker for their opinion on what to do next.

q: A client with a history of falls is admitted to the unit. Which of the following is a key component of a coordinated care plan to prevent falls?
answers: Keeping the call light within reach and ensuring the client knows how to use it.
Placing the client in a room farthest from the nursing station.
Keeping all four side rails up on the bed at all times.
Administering a sedative to keep the client calm.

q: Discharge planning for a client should begin at what point?
answers: Upon admission to the healthcare facility.
On the day of discharge.
Once the physician writes the discharge order.
When the client's insurance company requests it.

q: Which statement by a UAP indicates that the LVN needs to provide further instruction on the UAP's role?
answers: 'I will tell the patient about their new test results as soon as they come back.'
'I will let you know if the client's blood pressure is higher than 140/90.'
'I will help the client with their shower after breakfast.'
'I will record the client's urine output on the chart.'

q: A client is placed on contact precautions. The LVN is delegating care to a UAP. Which action requires the LVN's intervention?
answers: The UAP exits the room without removing their gown and gloves.
The UAP dons a gown and gloves before entering the room.
The UAP uses a dedicated stethoscope that is kept in the room.
The UAP performs hand hygiene after leaving the room.

q: The LVN is acting as a witness when a client signs a consent form. What does the LVN's signature on the form indicate?
answers: That the LVN observed the client voluntarily sign the form.
That the LVN has provided a detailed explanation of the procedure.
That the LVN agrees with the client's decision.
That the client is fully competent to make the decision.

q: A client has the right to confidentiality under HIPAA. Which of the following is a violation of this right?
answers: Discussing a client's condition with a coworker in the hospital cafeteria.
Giving a report to the oncoming nurse about the client's status.
Consulting with the physical therapist about the client's mobility.
Informing the client's insurance company of their diagnosis for billing purposes.

q: The LVN is planning care for four clients. Which client is the highest priority?
answers: A client who just returned from surgery and has no audible breath sounds on one side.
A client who is complaining of 6/10 incisional pain and has pain medication due.
A client who needs to be taught how to use an incentive spirometer.
A client who is stable and ready for their scheduled wound care.

q: Continuity of care is best ensured by which of the following actions?
answers: Providing a thorough and accurate handoff report at the end of the shift.
Completing all documentation at the very end of the shift.
Only taking care of the same patients every day.
Asking the patient's family to relay information between nurses.

q: Which of the following is an example of a breach of client confidentiality?
answers: Looking up the lab results of a celebrity who is a patient in another unit.
Reporting a case of suspected child abuse to the appropriate authorities.
Informing the pharmacist of a patient's allergy before dispensing medication.
Taking a photo of an interesting wound for a medical journal after obtaining patient consent.

q: An LVN is the team leader. Which principle is most important when delegating tasks?
answers: Ensuring the task is within the scope of practice for the person receiving it.
Giving the most difficult tasks to the most experienced UAP.
Delegating all tasks related to hygiene to the UAP.
Assigning tasks based on which UAP the LVN prefers to work with.

q: A client has a legal document that outlines their wishes for end-of-life care, including refusal of artificial nutrition. This document is known as a:
answers: Living Will.
Durable Power of Attorney for Finances.
Last Will and Testament.
Informed Consent.

q: The LVN needs to contact a physician about a client's worsening condition. Which statement reflects the 'Assessment' part of the SBAR framework?
answers: 'I think the client is developing pulmonary edema.'
'The client is a 68-year-old male admitted yesterday with heart failure.'
'The client's oxygen saturation has dropped from 95% to 88% in the last hour.'
'I recommend that you order a dose of furosemide and a chest x-ray.'

q: Which activity is a primary responsibility of the LVN and should NOT be delegated?
answers: Performing a focused assessment on a client reporting dizziness.
Assisting a client with their meal tray.
Taking routine vital signs on a stable patient.
Transporting a client to the radiology department.

q: A client is being discharged with a new prescription. Which action best demonstrates coordinated care?
answers: Confirming that the client knows the name of the pharmacy where the prescription was sent.
Handing the client a printed list of all their medications.
Telling the client to call their doctor if they have any questions.
Assuming the client's family will handle picking up the medication.

q: An LVN overhears a physician telling a client, 'If you don't agree to this procedure, you'll have to find another doctor.' The LVN should recognize this as a potential case of:
answers: Coercion.
Negligence.
Libel.
Malpractice.

q: What is the LVN's primary role in the client admission process?
answers: Contributing to the ongoing data collection and helping to develop the care plan.
Completing the comprehensive initial nursing assessment.
Developing the final discharge plan for the client.
Providing all the initial client education.

q: A UAP reports to the LVN that a client who is normally alert and oriented is now confused. What should the LVN do first?
answers: Go to the client's room and assess them personally.
Tell the UAP to recheck the client's vital signs in 30 minutes.
Call the physician and report the UAP's findings.

q: A client's family has a question about the results of a recent MRI scan. The LVN has not seen the results. What is the LVN's best response?
answers: 'I will contact the physician to discuss the results with you.'
'I'm not allowed to share test results, you'll have to wait for the doctor.'
'I can look them up and tell you what I think they mean.'
'Everything is probably fine, test results can take a while.'

q: Which of these is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)?
answers: Leaving a computer with patient information visible in a public area.
Using a patient's initials on a whiteboard at the nurse's station.
Faxing a patient's medical records to a consulting specialist's office.
Providing a patient with a copy of their own medical records.

q: An LVN is delegating tasks for a client on droplet precautions. Which instruction is most important to give the UAP?
answers: 'You must wear a surgical mask when you are within 3 feet of the client.'
'You must wear a full N95 respirator at all times in the room.'

Assisting a client with using a bedpan.
Performing passive range-of-motion exercises.
Applying a barrier cream to a client's skin.

q: The five rights of delegation include right task, right circumstance, right person, right direction/communication, and what other right?
answers: Right supervision/evaluation.
Right time.
Right documentation.
Right equipment.

Assessment.
Implementation.
Evaluation.

q: What does the 'A' in the SBAR communication tool stand for?
answers: Assessment.
Action.
Admission.

q: A client states they want to leave against medical advice (AMA). Which of the following is an essential nursing action?

q: A client's family member is very loud and disruptive at the nursing station. What is the LVN's most appropriate initial action?

q: What is the primary reason for conducting a thorough handoff report between shifts?

q: The LVN is a member of the ethics committee at the hospital. This is an example of which type of professional role?
answers: An organizational role.

q: A client's daughter has durable power of attorney for healthcare. The client is alert and oriented and makes a decision that the daughter disagrees with. Who has the final say?

q: Which task can the LVN delegate to a UAP for a client in skeletal traction?

q: A client asks the LVN to be a witness for their Last Will and Testament. What is the most appropriate response for the LVN?

Administering a resident's daily insulin injection.

q: The LVN is prioritizing care for a group of clients. Which client's need is most urgent?

q: Which of the following is the best example of a nurse acting as a client advocate?
